segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Adding navigation
segment.target: Adding navigation

segment.source: iOS provides the UINavigationController class to help with in-app navigation: you can push and pop views to create the hierarchy of UIViewControllers that define your app.
segment.target: iOS provides the UINavigationController class to help with in-app navigation: you can push and pop views to create the hierarchy of UIViewControllers that define your app.

segment.source: In contrast, a Windows 10 app containing multiple views takes more of a web-site approach to navigation.
segment.target: In contrast, a Windows 10 app containing multiple views takes more of a web-site approach to navigation.

segment.source: You can imagine your users hopping from page to page as they click on controls to work their way through the app.
segment.target: You can imagine your users hopping from page to page as they click on controls to work their way through the app.

segment.source: For more info, see Navigation design basics.
segment.target: For more info, see Navigation design basics.

segment.source: One of the ways to manage this navigation in a Windows 10 app is to use the Frame class.
segment.target: One of the ways to manage this navigation in a Windows 10 app is to use the Frame class.

segment.source: The following walkthrough shows you how to try this out.
segment.target: The following walkthrough shows you how to try this out.

segment.source: Continuing with the solution you started earlier, open the MainPage.xaml file, and add a button in the Design view.
segment.target: Continuing with the solution you started earlier, open the MainPage.xaml file, and add a button in the Design view.

segment.source: Change the button's Content property from "Button" to "Go To Page".
segment.target: Change the button's Content property from "Button" to "Go To Page".

segment.source: Then, create a handler for the button's Click event, as shown in the following figure.
segment.target: Then, create a handler for the button's Click event, as shown in the following figure.

segment.source: If you don't remember how to do this, review the walkthrough in the previous section (Hint: double-click the button in the Design view).
segment.target: If you don't remember how to do this, review the walkthrough in the previous section (Hint: double-click the button in the Design view).

segment.source: adding a button and its click event in visual studio
segment.target: adding a button and its click event in visual studio

segment.source: Let's add a new page.
segment.target: Let's add a new page.

segment.source: In the Solution view, tap the Project menu, and tap Add New Item.
segment.target: In the Solution view, tap the Project menu, and tap Add New Item.

segment.source: Tap Blank Page as shown in the following figure, and then tap Add.
segment.target: Tap Blank Page as shown in the following figure, and then tap Add.

segment.source: adding a new page in visual studio
segment.target: adding a new page in visual studio

segment.source: Next, add a button to the BlankPage.xaml file.
segment.target: Next, add a button to the BlankPage.xaml file.

segment.source: Let's use the AppBarButton control, and let's give it a back arrow image: in the XAML view, add between the elements.
segment.target: Let's use the AppBarButton control, and let's give it a back arrow image: in the XAML view, add between the elements.

segment.source: Now, let's add an event handler to the button: double-click the control in the Design view and Microsoft Visual Studio adds the text "AppBarButton\_Click" to the Click box, as shown in the following figure, and then adds and displays the corresponding event handler in the BlankPage.xaml.cs file.
segment.target: Now, let's add an event handler to the button: double-click the control in the Design view and Microsoft Visual Studio adds the text "AppBarButton\_Click" to the Click box, as shown in the following figure, and then adds and displays the corresponding event handler in the BlankPage.xaml.cs file.

segment.source: adding a back button and its click event in visual studio
segment.target: adding a back button and its click event in visual studio

segment.source: If you return to the BlankPage.xaml file's XAML view, the element's Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML) code should now look like this:
segment.target: If you return to the BlankPage.xaml file's XAML view, the element's Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML) code should now look like this:

segment.source: Return to the BlankPage.xaml.cs file, and add this code to go to the previous page after the user taps the button.
segment.target: Return to the BlankPage.xaml.cs file, and add this code to go to the previous page after the user taps the button.

segment.source: Finally, open the MainPage.xaml.cs file and add this code.
segment.target: Finally, open the MainPage.xaml.cs file and add this code.

segment.source: It opens BlankPage after the user taps the button.
segment.target: It opens BlankPage after the user taps the button.

segment.source: Now, run the program.
segment.target: Now, run the program.

segment.source: Tap the "Go To Page" button to go to the other page, and then tap the back-arrow button to return to the previous page.
segment.target: Tap the "Go To Page" button to go to the other page, and then tap the back-arrow button to return to the previous page.

segment.source: Page navigation is managed by the Frame class.
segment.target: Page navigation is managed by the Frame class.

segment.source: As the UINavigationController class in iOS uses pushViewController and popViewController methods, the Frame class for Windows Store apps provides Navigate and GoBack methods.
segment.target: As the UINavigationController class in iOS uses pushViewController and popViewController methods, the Frame class for Windows Store apps provides Navigate and GoBack methods.

segment.source: The Frame class also has a method called GoForward, which does what you might expect.
segment.target: The Frame class also has a method called GoForward, which does what you might expect.

segment.source: This walkthrough creates a new instance of BlankPage each time you navigate to it.
segment.target: This walkthrough creates a new instance of BlankPage each time you navigate to it.

segment.source: (The previous instance will be freed, or released, automatically).
segment.target: (The previous instance will be freed, or released, automatically).

segment.source: If you don't want a new instance to be created each time, add the following code to the BlankPage class's constructor in the BlankPage.xaml.cs file.
segment.target: If you don't want a new instance to be created each time, add the following code to the BlankPage class's constructor in the BlankPage.xaml.cs file.

segment.source: This will enable the NavigationCacheMode behavior.
segment.target: This will enable the NavigationCacheMode behavior.

segment.source: You can also get or set the Frame class's CacheSize property to manage how many pages in the navigation history can be cached.
segment.target: You can also get or set the Frame class's CacheSize property to manage how many pages in the navigation history can be cached.

segment.source: For more info about navigation, see Navigation and XAML personality animations sample.
segment.target: For more info about navigation, see Navigation and XAML personality animations sample.

segment.source: Note For info about navigation for Windows Store apps using JavaScript and HTML, see Quickstart: Using single-page navigation.
segment.target: Note For info about navigation for Windows Store apps using JavaScript and HTML, see Quickstart: Using single-page navigation.
